newsitem.title: USA: Brazil imports sink U.S. soybean prices.
newsitem.headline: Brazil imports sink U.S. soybean prices.

text.p: Confirmation that U.S. processors are turning to Brazil to buy soybeans prompted a sharp selloff in Chicago futures on Wednesday but the imports are unlikely to have a long-term price impact, analysts said.

"It's going to be negative for the cash market for a while because it takes away some premium," said Dale Durchholz, grain analyst with Agrivisor Services in Bloomington, Ill. "But total world consumption is still strong," he said.
U.S. soybean stockpiles are at the lowest levels in 20 years due to booming exports, and prices this spring have climbed to levels not seen since a Midwestern drought in 1988.

On Wednesday, citing the tight U.S. soybean supplies, Minneapolis-based grain giant Cargill Inc issued a carefully worded statement confirming it had contracted to purchase an unspecified quantity of Brazilian soybeans.
"To carry us through this period, Cargill and other companies have turned to the global market for additional supplies," the company said.
Grain imports into the United States, the top grain exporter, remain a touchy issue with American farmers, since the purchases benefit competing overseas farmers and pressure U.S. farm prices.
Earlier this year, Owensboro Grain, a small crusher in Kentucky, bought several cargos of soybeans from Brazil but later cancelled at least one cargo.

In January 1985, Cargill shocked U.S. farm circles by announcing a plan to import 25,000 tonnes of Argentine wheat to supply flour millers on the U.S. Gulf Coast at a time of high domestic wheat prices.
Cargill soon withdrew the plan but it prompted U.S. Senate hearings to discuss U.S. grain competitiveness a month later.
Brazil is currently the number one competitor for the United States in selling soybeans to world markets.
"You'll hear some grumbling and you'll hear it talked about around the coffee table," Durchholz said of the Brazilian imports. "But it's all about making money and they (farmers) understand that."

Soybeans for July delivery at the Chicago Board of Trade closed down the 30-cent-per-bushel daily limit at $8.30 on Wednesday. That was down from a high of $8.86 last Friday before rumours of soybean imports began to circulate.
Cargill said it would use the soybeans to supply its plants in the U.S. Southeast, which provide soymeal and other feeds to livestock and poultry producers.

Also on Wednesday, the Brazilian processor Ceval Alimentos said it was negotiating a sale of 40,000 metric tons of soymeal for shipment to the United States. Traders said the buyer was likely a large pork producer on the East Coast.
That news helped send July soymeal at the exchange down the $10 a ton daily limit to close at $273.10 a ton.

Durchholz said news of Brazilian soy imports should not come as a surprise because U.S. commercial firms began to look at Brazil as a cheaper source of soybeans as soon as that country began actively harvesting in March.
Despite the sharp drop in Chicago prices Wednesday, the market is supported long term by strong world demand, he said.
"The fact is, that exports are still okay for this time of year. We're crushing more than we did recently and the overall off-take in the world is still quite good," Durchholz said.
Traders said the psychological impact of Brazilian imports this year was muted by the switch to a more market-based farm economy in the U.S. and by historically low soybean stocks.
Big imports also aren't expected because shipping soybeans from Brazil only works out financially for soybean processors that have plants located near major U.S. ports, analysts said.
